title: 3 Important Conversations to Have With Your Teen

content: My boys just celebrated their 14 th and 12 th birthdays. All I can think is, “How in the world did this happen so fast?” Everything you hear about parenting really is true. Time. Just. Flies. I would even argue that if you are managing potentially life-threatening food allergies, the days turn into weeks, months, and years even more quickly. As a parent, you have your head down trying to triple-check every ingredient and every decision to ensure your child’s safety as they grow. And then one day you look up, and you have TEENAGERS!

Of course, there are so many important issues to teach your teens. But if they have food allergies, there are extra concerns to consider. I’ve had several topics in my head as “to-do” chats for a long while, but suddenly I realized the time is now .

My parenting philosophy has always been to be open and honest with my kids, and have all the talks , preferably well before they are needed, so my boys are armed with knowledge as they grow into their lives. I’d like to caveat that I’m very aware of protecting my boys’ privacy, even as I write for this public blog, so please note that they haven’t done anything “wrong” to cause these conversations.

content: Also, take into account that I’m using the term “teenager” loosely for the preteen and teen years starting around age 12. However, these chats are applicable to any child who is spending time independently and/or has access to the internet. The earlier the better!

With that said, there are three big conversations I’m having with my boys these days about managing food allergies during their teen years. I thought I’d share them with you here in case it’s helpful for your family discussions.

This might seem like an easy decision, since food allergy families know to carry epinephrine and have had this conversation 1 million times. At least that’s true in our family. However, something happens in the teen brain, and information seems to leak out like in a sieve. I’m sure it has something to do with hormones, or a not fully matured prefrontal cortex, or even just typical teen feelings of independence and invincibility. But trust me, no matter how many times you’ve had this talk, and how sure you are that your teens know to carry their epinephrine, you need to discuss it again.

With that said, there are three big conversations I’m having with my boys these days about managing food allergies during their teen years. I thought I’d share them with you here in case it’s helpful for your family discussions.

This might seem like an easy decision, since food allergy families know to carry epinephrine and have had this conversation 1 million times. At least that’s true in our family. However, something happens in the teen brain, and information seems to leak out like in a sieve. I’m sure it has something to do with hormones, or a not fully matured prefrontal cortex, or even just typical teen feelings of independence and invincibility. But trust me, no matter how many times you’ve had this talk, and how sure you are that your teens know to carry their epinephrine, you need to discuss it again.

content: Please take time to remind your teens of all the reasons why they must carry epinephrine auto-injectors (two!), every single time they leave the house. And while you are at it, have them practice self-administering it, too. I compare carrying epinephrine to putting on a seatbelt when you get in the car – it is just something we do, without question, every time. You might be surprised if they push back, as if they no longer need to carry epinephrine, or act like this is new information. If so, you’ll be so glad you had the conversation. Keep having it – again, and again, and again! There is no downside to ensuring they understand all the reasons they need epinephrine to stay safe.

Ensuring that our kids are safe every day in real life can be overwhelming. And now we add the dangers that exist in the digital world where they are growing up. While there is a growing amount of research about the harms of smartphones and social media for young brains, let’s focus on our food-allergic kids seeking out medical information online. As adults, we are all guilty of looking to “Dr. Google” about our medical symptoms, and we know that this can often result in inaccurate or scary information from untrustworthy sources.

content: If your teens have access to the internet, they are going to search for medical information themselves, sooner rather than later. So, add this topic to your list of discussions to have. Let them know that not all medical information online (via websites or social media creators and groups) is accurate. Not only that, but what they find might also be emotional and overwhelming.

Urge them to come to you or discuss any questions they have about their food allergies directly with their doctor. Then show them sites you trust for accurate food allergy information, so that if they do want to do their own research online, they are looking at reliable resources. My favorites are Food Allergy Research & Information (FARE), Allergic Living, Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Connection Team (FAACT), and right here on WebMD. FARE even has a specific section for adolescents and teens, along with an active national teen group that meets on Zoom for seminars and moderated discussions.

sections.heading: K-i-s-s-i-n-g
content: This is sure to be your teen’s favorite food allergy-related conversation. Kidding! But it’s so important to have this one early, before that first kiss. Did you know there was an actual “kissing study” done in 2006 that measured how long peanut protein stayed in someone’s mouth after they consumed it? It showed that it took a few hours plus eating another, non-peanut-containing, meal to make sure all traces were gone.

What does this mean for your teen? Brushing teeth, rinsing out mouths, or chewing gum won’t get rid of food allergens. As unromantic as this might seem, your teen must learn to ask their crush what they’ve eaten that day before kissing. Is that awkward? Maybe. But remind them that a potential reaction would be worse.

Ideally, kissing won’t start until your teen knows their significant other well enough to have had the “allergy chat” so their partner knows not to eat food allergens on days they spend time together. After that initial conversation, it will get easier moving forward as they choose outings that don’t involve the food allergens. But, looping back to how teens can be forgetful: Make sure your kiddos know to keep reminding their dates not to eat their allergens over the course of their courtship, just in case.

sections.heading: Time Flies When You’re Having Fun …
content: … and when you’re raising teenagers. I hope these three conversation ideas are helpful to you and your child who isn’t so little anymore. I always feel like information is power, and so I try to arm my boys with as much knowledge as possible, even if the conversation feels redundant (for me) or even embarrassing (for them). Ensuring that they are safe, and that we have open communication between us, is worth it. So, go for it, parents! Have these talks with your teen … again and again. And then again!
